EE14272852DB4B9A8085A97DD86D704E.description: Develop and/or revise personal and career goals based on the work placement experience.

4864A701C4B64FA2B5FC5E9E57592518.description: Prepare a letter, note, card or other communication for the work placement employer, expressing appreciation.

EAB05B182E9A419B8025163A38731B77.description: Update personal career documentation (e.g., resume, portfolio) following the work placement.

BD484C903933452A80BD63C9DBDA94A2.description: Reflect on the attainment of personal and learning goals.

10A5A8789A204375B55E8CBAD3873963.description: Showcase one’s skills and abilities demonstrated during the work placement using artifacts, evidence of skill development and personal reflections on aspects of the work experience such as: hours worked; responsibilities and tasks performed; the importance of attitude towards work and taking responsibility for what needs to be done; details about the entry level wage, salary scales and earning potential; worker rights and responsibilities and the role of the union, if applicable; ownership structure (e.g., corporation, franchise, sole proprietorship, partnership); and, opportunities for advancement at the workplace and elsewhere in the industry

7AB3C6005C6242F286C1B5A28DA58626.description: Relate one’s work placement experience to personal and career goals.

1DDFA440715842C2A4C3AEDC6F398AE9.description: Document knowledge and awareness of employment standards, safety, workplace ethics, rights and responsibilities, occupational health and safety, and networking observed during the work placement.

3B6E0E60DB2A400E99B370F6C8D1430E.description: Document one’s experience using electronic and other tools (e.g., vlogs, blogs, log sheets, reflective journals) to summarize and reflect upon items such as: hours of work including breaks; responsibilities and tasks performed; interactions with the employer, staff, customers and others; company or organization’s ‘raison d’être;’ and, skills developed and demonstrated during the work placement that enhance one’s employability.

C03DD002DEED482EA0601577D40F4A03.description: Apply relevant skills and abilities during the work placement experience.

0E2FE90AAA204C5EB2E3B040E43C5107.description: Participate in a work placement experience.

97939841F0AD4ED19B64D3322C3C80B2.description: Reflect upon one’s performance during the interview.

9A41A2615C1B49F58CD6BBBF2C8555D4.description: Participate in an interview with the employer prior to beginning the work placement.

726B6F13AC1440E192192D73B5FA0284.description: Develop a list of questions that could potentially be asked by the employer/work placement in an interview situation as well as answers to the questions

A190E3E2CDF1445EAF2D0D4D98CE24B2.description: Brainstorm a list of questions to ask the employer before beginning the work placement; these may include: What is my schedule of work hours? Who is my supervisor? What should I wear? When will I be provided with safety training? What potential hazards might I encounter in the work placement? Where do I find fire extinguishers, first aid kits and emergency assistance? What type of safety gear am I expected to wear? Is it provided?, What should I do if I get injured or have an accident in the workplace?, How can I contact my health and safety committee or representative?, Are there any health and safety procedures I should follow?, Who is the first aid person?, Where are safety notices posted?, What should I do in case of a fire or emergency?

241A0871A28647D28AD1BF2CCC415CDD.description: Compile an employer information package that includes documents needed for the work placement (e.g., personal career documentation such as a resume or portfolio, permission forms, logs, self- and employer evaluation forms).

95B16D84128544F9929775F81DE01665.description: Develop a procedural guide for the work placement that includes items such as: transportation to and from the work placement; hours of work; guidelines for absence and tardiness; dress code; job description; and, conflict resolution

B1D732B90FEC460D8E7DDB18A481A769.description: In collaboration with all partners, develop personal and learning goals for the work placement.

14DE265A7BAA410EBF08EF61C742D648.description: Research the business/organization to become familiar with its operations

BD26F79743C248AAAE129AE95C959567.description: Explain the roles and responsibilities of each partner (e.g., student, parent, teacher or other school staff, employer) involved in the work placement.

A20B2DFA00C2458BA127EA8A118E2E73.description: Describe and reflect on the three basic rights that all workers have under Part III – Occupational Health and Safety in The Saskatchewan Employment Act, 2019: the right to know – the hazards at work and how to control them; the right to participate – in finding and controlling workplace hazards; and, the right to refuse – work that you believe is unusually dangerous.

1512D5B14790402F8C155453029D47CD.description: Consider the advantages (e.g., improved efficiency) and disadvantages (e.g., start-up costs) of investing in technology to increase revenue in livestock production.

D26E736A6B2748E088F462CA2932310B.description: Research a specific technology being developed or adapted for livestock in precision agriculture.

05D193E2432741FE87FE5B580AC3DD49.description: Examine the impact technology has on the overall cost of livestock production.

47632032139141F0B067859D67BD4DCD.description: Discuss the use of blockchain as a system to manage livestock records that are completely transparent.

28F6521B4CE74F82A54AEFD988569320.description: Investigate the use of weather stations to maximize pasture health.

B6E08323CECE4464BDE95154775D7F3A.description: Explore how robotics can be used to automate specific on a farm tasks (e.g., egg sorting and milking machines).

56E697B6B0954358B405B50FD18EF7A8.description: Examine how drones can be used in gathering data and performing tasks (e.g., livestock identification and tracking) in precision agriculture.

A98B6B363CAE49D0B95CCBDBEFE80264.description: Assess the advantages, disadvantages and safety requirements when using self-driving vehicles in livestock operations.

D918025377B04AD49D546DCAEB4634D6.description: Explore the use of specialized technology in livestock production.

B68E6932C8D94131B108526CA7EE2375.description: Precision Agriculture – Specialized Technology for Livestock Production (Optional)

AA8AF4016BC841AEAA024AF5C7EB55E2.description: Describe the advantages and disadvantages of using a desiccant before harvest.

8B746E1618C04311993B19FEB9F7FB01.description: Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of different methods of preventing product resistance from occurring (e.g., rotating pesticides and crop rotations).

2DC993ACB9224B2BB7006E8FC4013A47.description: Explore product resistance in a plant population including the types of resistance found in Saskatchewan field crops.

6674E47A97CB411C8B4A51A5597F7F6D.description: Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of Integrated Pest Management.

487DB82CB32541AA8DE405DCA52953BB.description: Describe the safe operation of hand and large equipment sprayers.

52D9C675C4804B65AF9ADB419B79B8A4.description: Identify key components of a sprayer (e.g., pump, nozzle, boom and shut off valve).

9B1B749D0B244A5DAC35EA1CBB139F19.description: Analyze advantages and disadvantages of various product application methods (e.g., seed treatments, high clearance sprayer and aerial application).

2E0B205F97894DBFBCC9177DFED94B81.description: Explain the concept of biosecurity and how it relates to protecting crops

F0B932523E964AD89DBB7F9D0130397C.description: Describe proper scouting techniques to determine infestation levels and product effectiveness.

31E2AE011368496D8BB1E24EDC7F4A7D.description: Determine appropriate pesticide, herbicide and fungicide products and application rate for various pests, weeds and diseases.

9C29F1B922BC4B39A6F6ED7BC95C4459.description: Identify the economic thresholds for various diseases and insect infestations in a pulse, cereal and oilseed rotation.

4A91F4EA507647448C273C142FB631B6.description: Identify beneficial insects that may be found in a cereal, pulse, oilseed rotation and the pests they attack.

7C344B50148C41EB9BDA3294C696F378.description: Identify various pests, weeds and diseases that could occur in cereal, pulse and oilseed crop rotations.

3478240C858744BFB8AAC5652F76B1FE.description: Explore the use of pesticides, herbicides, fungicides and desiccants.

0C2C7AF337784C80AB369AAE3BCB66D3.description: Crop Health Care – Pesticides, Herbicides, Fungicides and Desiccants (Optional)

92B9D12D265346C8A39E8FBE18906381.description: Investigate the impact of plant protein production on, and Canada’s role in, global food sustainability.

79F66019A0934235A3EF89807398D24F.description: Debate the advantages and disadvantages of using genetically modified organisms (GMOs) to increase plant protein levels.

65D99165B7334CC9821DA429F0A91481.description: Analyze the energy and resource cost for creating one pound of protein from animals compared to plants.

E80037AEBD5244AEB308C407B7262863.description: Research how producers are improving the quality of protein feedstock derived from Saskatchewan crops.

01E97237CE4642DD8A27280A7730A557.description: Explain the benefit of including pulse crops in crop rotation.

FD8AA08F2176449A9BBAB63B598D02DA.description: Explain the benefit of including pulse crops in crop rotation.

B03826CC8C9044CFAC427A46EF80DDAB.description: Explore the production of plant protein by producers.

6DD160C250994A4EA1F102102AA8D159.description: Investigate the process that is involved in transitioning to organic farming including economic considerations (e.g., crop yield and crop price).

A35E5037DDC7474B8EACC48DBBDED110.description: Research how organic farm operations prepare for an inspection.

A2B23D0D0B824213BE99C9672036D8C4.description: Explore the traceability of crop products to prove organic status.

9F1026B5398541DBBC229D57B9FE1772.description: Investigate the standards and regulations for organic crop production as determined by the Canadian Food Inspection Agency (CFIA).

9F4D95498DBF40E18D7B20A60BA4BECD.description: Explore the management of organic crop production.

726ECE17422443848DDFC9484FB63327.description: Explore how collected data is analyzed to inform necessary changes to the production operation.

F05735BDC85F477AA5227B90BD779DA5.description: Develop a record keeping plan for a crop rotation, which includes: seasonal activities (e.g., seeding dates, spraying quantities and harvesting yield); equipment maintenance; crop management (e.g., crop varieties, yield, fertility levels, weather tracking, field inspections, crop rotation and disease and insect issues and their treatment); financial management (e.g., inventory, storage, bin checks, prices, markets, sales, purchases and shipments); and, risk management (e.g., crop insurance and claim history for each crop and field).

D0088D8DE4424572B273F202AF2A8DFC.description: Describe how records can be used to communicate between people (e.g., employers and employees, co-workers, grain specialists, agrologists, suppliers and end consumers) involved in a farming operation.

2FAE3C324F564D55B64CE350B2B54BF7.description: Crop Record Keeping – Planning and Analysis (Optional)

ACE2CB1F7CF24B61905748647487FD94.description: Describe the dangers of overhead power lines when moving farm equipment.

2522813756AB46F5945F355DC8098767.description: List examples of tools and emergency equipment required on farm machinery while in transport on a public road.

725EC08867F04BEAB6AA37E817CBDF9D.description: Discuss the importance of a transportation logbook.

B6669BCEDBB540C884B52A4EFAEB3824.description: Examine provincial and federal livestock transportation regulations (e.g., types of trailers, food and water requirements, manifest and the amount of time livestock can be hauled).

0B61813749AC4770A8A687747AEEB6FD.description: Explore the requirements or exemption status for agricultural equipment and vehicles in the transportation of dangerous goods.

F18E1E189935401D8196F4661913FCCF.description: Discuss the implications that seasonal road restrictions have on a farming operation (e.g., marketing and labor requirements).

15F2F88948E04F7F89604B7423DE28CC.description: Investigate the Ministry of Highways requirements (e.g., permits, restrictions such as width-height-length and weight, lighting, slow moving signs, clear visibility rules and escort vehicle requirements) to transport farm equipment, livestock and grain on provincial highways and roads.

675405E187244642BDE5853C46371439.description: Identify the licensing, insurance and operator’s qualifications for handling different types of farm equipment on private land and public roads

3C83B814F6844FA6B20575404AD3114F.description: Explore transportation regulations including the movement of farm equipment and livestock on public roads.

67506844876B4C539AA91B4C4FE295BC.description: Prepare an effective time management schedule that balances farm time with school, work and recreation and considers seasonal time management.

7D5FE5BBD50C41BE80C3B0E05C7552DD.description: Discuss the financial considerations needed for a chosen multi-product operation including human and equipment resources, types of products, seasonal and foreign workers, buy or lease equipment options, outsourcing stages, accessibility to markets, cost of input, grazing / harvesting restrictions associated with specific chemicals that are used in weed, insect and disease control for crops and expected revenue.

6E052D3F9A514BE8AB08539457B27382.description: Identify the fertilizers and chemicals to be used for crops in a chosen multi-product operation.

D0555F9DE7E540CD8B1A262F76A53F1C.description: Explore the crop rotation best suited for a chosen multi-product operation.

70B5D6389AFB47DBBDD17F462A6B3C05.description: Identify planting and harvesting methods for the crops grown in a chosen multi-product operation.

C6E865A202D4434A9E37AE7E1AB587B9.description: Develop a livestock nutrition program for a chosen multi-product operation, including the use of crops for feed, feed storage, method of feeding, grazing methods and sources of water.

907CE1337C2045228D373756BCD3DC18.description: Investigate livestock management practices (e.g., percentage as meat processing, crossbreeding and introduction of new animals), the handling of manure as fertilizer and herd protection measures (e.g., herd dogs, donkeys and structures).

778C7D22A5A84C299C60B0235BB15310.description: Analyze the suitability of farm locations (e.g., soil type, landforms and climate) for a chosen multi-product operation.

151778D9665143FD976652AF5E571327.description: Explore the structures (e.g., buildings, fences and corrals) and land (e.g., land features including soil types and use of that land) needed for a chosen mixed operation.

869FABC792354F2A8214DA5690625F31.description: Determine the annual and production cycle date ranges for chosen crop and livestock species.

B7186610AD6E40A8843F0B294CB56F01.description: Identify one or more species of crops (e.g., wheat, barley, canola, lentils, fruits and vegetables) and livestock (e.g., cow/calf, dairy, equine, pork, bison, egg production and bee keeping) that are suitable for a mixed operation.

26C3A0C027E346188443EC9D005C505F.description: Examine the role of livestock in a mixed operation (e.g., nutrient cycle, feeding crops to build organic matter in soil and livestock grazing for weed control).

292D66037BFF4FD6A0D98CB6C4801F72.description: Investigate the benefits (e.g., grain to feed livestock, manure to fertilize crops and financial coverage when one operation is less successful) of having crop and livestock production in the same operation.

410BB9BF7ADB4750865B8E1EF447ADCA.description: Prepare a management plan for an operation involving one or more specific crop and livestock species.

3DCB35A9CF08461C97195F996202DB94.description: Prepare an effective time management schedule that balances farm time with school, recreation and work and considers seasonal time management differences.

CB756AEC72DB488FA910E69A285201D6.description: Describe the implications of climate change (e.g., drought, deluge and storms) on the growth, harvesting and yield of crops.

CEB972300BEB48239BD6022FB45521F4.description: Analyze the finances of a crop operation including seasonal workers, buy or lease equipment options, accessibility to markets, cost of input, cash input advances, crop insurance, forward contracting, the risks versus the advantages of forward contracting and expected revenue.

5480695C5FB04C2F9B73A1DF98DC31E5.description: Describe the process, advantages and disadvantages in applying chemicals (e.g., pre-plant, pre-emergence and post emergence) and fertilizers (e.g., broadcast, seed placed, mid row and side banded) to chosen crops.

F09FD899A8EC4AA8AB7B25112969D886.description: Explain which fertilizers and chemicals can be used for a chosen crop rotation.

657575EEA77245929BB3A1E6B2917C37.description: Identify harvesting methods for crops in a rotation (e.g., swathing, baling, green chopping and straight cutting) and the advantages and disadvantages of using crop desiccation products.

1FEA6642BBF54807986BC07A23EEC796.description: Identify planting methods for crops in a rotation (e.g., air seeder, planter and specialized seeder for forage crops).

5E02F49A618643C7A873C246B28EFE87.description: Identify the farming cycle date ranges for a chosen crop rotation (e.g., impact of spring and fall frost dates and the reasons for the order of crops in the rotation).

757D9EEB7F75444F9FD63C32BAE98587.description: Identify the buildings and equipment required for a chosen crop production operation.

068DF621EC0C4134ABFFDC8FBBE798BB.description: Analyze the influence of soil types, land features and climate on the choice of crop rotation.

CA8D49C3BBCE44ED9495FB4A0BF73E9F.description: Explore the advantages and disadvantages of a two-year, three-year, four-year and longer crop rotation.

CABD4E8B000B4AB4B932F10D6DA69E33.description: Identify specific crops (e.g., wheat, canola, lentils, fruit, vegetables and forage) for a farm operation.

A7D5F8C17C3D44A4A90DE0A735503E4E.description: Prepare a management plan for an operation of one or more specific species of crop.

19E76B7CFE6D422B96F5672FE234960D.description: Explore the key principles and practice of regenerative agriculture.

685974F33E824E26B2568167D136CB2F.description: Examine the effectiveness of various farming methods (e.g., minimum tillage and crop rotation) for conserving soil health.

9C053F96AD9140D4A194919B1133D5A6.description: Research current methods (e.g., avoid overgrazing, cover crop and direct seeding) for reducing soil erosion

F46FC366A1084E06A9E08CA569B2F480.description: Explain the 4 Rs of nutrient stewardship: right source; right rate; right time; and, right place.

64DE133A504E4848AB4CC1F40BB8C5B7.description: Discuss the importance of historical and contemporary livestock and grain production practices that conserve water and maintain soil quality.

B6B4365A64DE4BAC8A40D7790EA74A52.description: Discuss Indigenous peoples' traditional values as they pertain to maintaining land and water health.

0758BCE1A4CC4E788979597A67675389.description: Explore the relationship between sustainability and water and soil quality.

B263BE9B053044489F012BB18AD0BADE.description: Explore soil conservation and stewardship in sustainable agriculture production.

A70A90C04C2B4666BBA458E7F878FDC6.description: Examine employers’ duty to accommodate employee requests as outlined in the Canadian Human Rights Code.

F4DA3D697EBB4CD69922DE10BD9C6553.description: Research employers’ duties and responsibilities to support workplace mental health as outlined in The Saskatchewan Employment Act.

965C80BB51624EE698FF288171A57C79.description: Discuss practical ways that employees can contribute to a psychologically healthy and safe workplace.

672F7E475A834BBEAD0F1E0C8EB722AE.description: Describe and suggest possible solutions for unavoidable stresses during peak operating times (e.g., harvest time, calving season and weather events) that employers face in providing accommodation requests.

F9BE07A3088F47DEB7D97E5777309CE4.description: Discuss barriers (e.g., lack of awareness of accommodations, lack of confidence in requesting help, where to find supports, social stigma, fear of reprisal and fear of rejection) that employees face in disclosing a mental health problem or illness and/or requesting accommodations

1F1192666CEB44449F01AEFB0C7220B7.description: Explore accommodations (e.g., flexible hours, job sharing and modifications to the work environment and duties) that can be requested by employees of businesses in an agriculture setting (e.g., farming operations, chemical companies and grain elevators) to support mental health during peak operating efficiency.

1DBF34AB3FD4471195165303E8B10EE0.description: Investigate employer and employee psychological health and safety in the workplace.

94CE2CF039E04BBBB4806C8483A6E3E1.description: Psychological Health and Safety – Employer and Employee (Core)

E7F3306298E84DA0B44AA2635625D50B.description: Practise the methods used to remove and dispose of chemical residue (e.g., fertilizer and pesticide spray) from application equipment.

BF9026F770624366B3403AB48D54AFFE.description: Explore the environmental impacts of unsafe chemical waste disposal, and how that impacts Indigenous communities (e.g., water, animals and traditional medicinal plants).

585700E8C80042E4829C7381A681C984.description: Investigate the responsibilities and correct environmental handling, cleanup and waste disposal of cleaners, containers, coolants, filters, fuel and lubricants (e.g., grease and oil) including organizations that specialize in their cleanup

413FCBB556414DC69B3049CDB8BD9F6D.description: Investigate regulations and responsibilities to safely dispose of leftover chemical and chemical containers.

498ED4F3B23443C5AFCE9B2922719FAD.description: Discuss first-aid procedures for exposure to agricultural chemicals (e.g., fertilizer, pesticide, fuel and anhydrous ammonia).

57263BAFFE794240A6126D575E0FE44C.description: Develop procedures for handling mishaps such as chemical spills.

12C30FA862324B7E8EE77C96E5A79C12.description: Practise the safe storage of chemical products.

BE3300B643A54833AA9405E125C86E16.description: Demonstrate safe handling of chemical products using approved safety gear.

067B9B6337604321B0D149DD7296E84B.description: Explain the uses of agricultural chemicals that would require a Saskatchewan Pesticide Applicator Licence.

F19650B5CD4A4CE5AF623D3255530E95.description: Explore training and certification opportunities (e.g., WHMIS and pesticide applicator licence) on the safe use of agricultural chemicals.

2BD9C7C8BD6D4868A6C9687588E324D8.description: Investigate record keeping strategies for maintaining SDS information.

B41B86312D144F8BA084C76667B1DBE2.description: Describe the potential heath risks of exposure to chemicals.

A84A8111A7A84B909C4E229B9CB8F1E7.description: Identify the types of hazardous materials that an agricultural operation might create.

A254A36E0E03473EB59998E0959CD272.description: Discuss the purpose and intended use of the mandatory information on a pesticide label as regulated by Health Canada.

B681250A9A3343CDB78BDCE11D91850B.description: Demonstrate the different hazards, identifiers and uses of consumer products, control products, and pesticides.

F2B44A6EE70C47149AA809C6FA50F1BA.description: Describe the four parts of Workplace Hazardous Materials Information System (WHMIS) (i.e., labels with warning symbols, hazard identification and product classification, Safety Data Sheets (SDS), worker education and worksite specific training).

71F4F6DB309343A59F46FAD95853D2F0.description: Identify important information categories from product labels, Material Safety Data Sheets (MSDS) and manufacturer’s chemical information packages such as compatibility, storage requirements, application method, preharvest intervals and withdrawal periods.

AAC71E851A6245B4A1A5F61C3AEE5452.description: Demonstrate the importance of, and methods used for, maintenance of a clean and safe workplace.

2D31F3C880BA48C2A01EA7217C667E93.description: Apply proper handling of hazardous materials to prevent injury in the workplace.

C221613D872246DA9B955985172EF60A.description: Develop a basic Farm Safety Plan that includes: why safety is an important part of the agricultural production business; a frequency for inspections of tools and equipment; requirements for reporting incidents to a supervisor; requirements for use and care of Personal Protective Equipment; requirements for minimum training of workers; how hazards will be identified; how hazards will be controlled; and, an emergency response plan.

B399443E5D4146D8B8675D59C9EB6444.description: Demonstrate the use of common agricultural production PPE according to the manufacturer’s requirements.

54D04A831F3242698556C6255524F246.description: Describe risks associated with buried underground services (e.g., SaskPower, SaskEnergy, SaskTel and oil transmission lines).

92A0D96A19F84157811134AEB0F9D2CD.description: Describe risks associated with above ground powerlines.

CC6F86CC008F4AADB383A653E2B73C7C.description: Demonstrate regular tool inspection and tag out procedures for repair of common tools used during agricultural production.

2808645D665F4AF08C96F98B33938EF6.description: Demonstrate the utilization and maintenance of protective devices on equipment.

E7D5DAED4E31488B8F27A9B39F3F5496.description: Develop a list of rules for workplace safety including proper personal protective equipment (PPE), sanitation, neat and tidy work area and reporting workplace accidents and safety incidents

370582C916BB4177953666BFE4C6B785.description: Perform basic safety procedures (e.g., storage and maintenance of tools, clean workspace, working at high heights and working around large equipment) as they apply to an agriculture production operation.

138E7169031740FEACA7E5BEABAAE7DE.description: Apply principles and techniques for injury prevention to ensure safety in agriculture production.
